title: Using harlem color palettes
code: # Use a discrete palette directly palette <- harlem_palettes$JonesAscentEthiopia  # Diamonds bar chart colored by cut p1 <- ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = cut, fill = cut)) +   geom_bar() +   scale_fill_manual(values = palette) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(title = "Count of diamonds by cut",        x = "Cut", y = "Count")  p1

title: Using harlem color palettes
code: # Build a continuous gradient from a palette continuous_cols <- harlem_palette("MotleyBlues", n = 256, type = "continuous")  # Use a scatter plot to demonstrate continuous color scale subset_diamonds <- diamonds[sample.int(nrow(diamonds), 2000), ]  p2 <- ggplot(subset_diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = price)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 1.2) +   scale_color_gradientn(colors = continuous_cols) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(title = "Scatter with continuous palette",        x = "Carat", y = "Price", color = "Price")  p2

what: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
text: goal harlem provide collection color palettes inspired iconic works Harlem Renaissance artists. palettes designed bring artistic flair data visualizations R. palette draws colors specific artwork: Jacob Lawrence – Street Scene (LawrenceStreetScene) Romare Bearden – Conjur Woman (BeardenConjurWoman), Collage (BeardenCollage included) Aaron Douglas – Aspects Negro Life (DouglasAspects), Song Towers (DouglasSongTowers) Archibald Motley – Blues (MotleyBlues), Nightlife (MotleyNightlife) William H. Johnson – Harlem (JohnsonHarlem), Going Church (JohnsonGoingChurch), Ascent Ethiopia (JonesAscentEthiopia) Loïs Mailou Jones – La Baker (JonesLaBaker), Ascent Ethiopia (JonesAscentEthiopia) Sargent Claude Johnson – Octoroon Girl (SargentOctoroonGirl) Beauford Delaney – Self-Portrait (DelaneySelfPortrait) Palmer Hayden – Fetiche et Fleurs (HaydenFetiche) Charles White – Soldier (CharlesWhiteSoldier) Hale Woodruff – Amistad Mutiny (WoodruffAmistad) using palettes, can incorporate vibrancy, contrast, cultural context Harlem Renaissance art directly ggplot2 charts R visualizations.

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
text: can install development version harlem GitHub Wwith:

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists

what: Example 1: Bar Plot Using the JonesAscentEthiopia Palette
title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
code: library(harlem) library(ggplot2)  data(diamonds, package = "ggplot2")  palette <- harlem_palettes$JonesAscentEthiopia ggplot(diamonds, aes(x = cut, fill = cut)) +      geom_bar() +     scale_fill_manual(values = palette) +     theme_minimal() +     labs(title = "Count of Diamonds by Cut",           x = "Cut", y = "Count")

what: Example 2: Scatter Plot Using the MotleyBlues Palette
title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
code: # Build a continuous gradient from a palette continuous_cols <- harlem_palette("MotleyBlues", n = 256, type = "continuous")  # Use a scatter plot to demonstrate continuous color scale set.seed(1) subset_diamonds <- diamonds[sample.int(nrow(diamonds), 2000), ]  ggplot(subset_diamonds, aes(x = carat, y = price, color = price)) +   geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 1.2) +   scale_color_gradientn(colors = continuous_cols) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(title = "Scatter with Motley Blues palette",        x = "Carat", y = "Price", color = "Price")

what: Example 3: Box Plot Using the CharlesWhiteSoldier Palette
title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
code: set.seed(123) df <- data.frame(     dose = factor(rep(1:5, each = 10)),     len = c(rnorm(10, 10, 3),             rnorm(10, 14, 3),             rnorm(10, 18, 3),             rnorm(10, 22, 3),             rnorm(10, 26, 3)) )  # Box plot p3 <- ggplot(df, aes(x = dose, y = len, fill = dose)) +     geom_boxplot(color = "black") +     scale_fill_manual(values = harlem_palettes$JohnsonGoingChurch) +     theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +     theme(legend.position = "top") +     labs(x = "dose", y = "len")  p3

title: Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
Color Palettes Inspired by Harlem Renaissance Artists
text: package provides two main functions: harlem_palettes: list containing available palettes harlem_palette(): function generate palettes options discrete continuous output print_palette(): function visualize palettes
code: # Get a specific palette harlem_palettes$MotleyBlues #> [1] "#8F1307" "#1F231C" "#BD8955" "#461303" "#6D1A08"  # Generate a continuous palette harlem_palette("MotleyBlues", n = 10, type = "continuous") #>  [1] "#8F1307" "#5D1A10" "#2B2119" "#53452E" "#997248" "#A26E42" "#6D3A1E" #>  [8] "#4A1303" "#5B1605" "#6D1A08" #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "palette" #> attr(,"name") #> [1] "MotleyBlues"  # Print a palette print_palette(harlem_palettes$LawrenceStreetScene)

title: harlem — harlem

title: Harlem Renaissance Palette Generator — harlem_palette
text: Generates color palettes inspired artworks Harlem Renaissance era.

title: Harlem Renaissance Palette Generator — harlem_palette
code: harlem_palette(   name = "LawrenceStreetScene",   n = NULL,   type = c("discrete", "continuous") )

title: Harlem Renaissance Palette Generator — harlem_palette
text: name Character string. Name desired palette. Available choices included package documentation. n Integer. Number colors desired. omitted, uses available colors chosen palette. type Character string. Either "continuous" "discrete". Use "continuous" interpolate colors.

title: Harlem Renaissance Palette Generator — harlem_palette
code: harlem_palette("LawrenceStreetScene") #> [1] "#C13E20" "#3E5D33" "#D7AA50" "#282828" "#E6E6E6" #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "palette" #> attr(,"name") #> [1] "LawrenceStreetScene" harlem_palette("BeardenConjurWoman", 5) #> [1] "#6da0c5" "#778889" "#af8a67" "#ffe1a4" "#4b3328" #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "palette" #> attr(,"name") #> [1] "BeardenConjurWoman" harlem_palette("MotleyBlues", type = "continuous") #> [1] "#8F1307" "#1F231C" "#BD8955" "#461303" "#6D1A08" #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "palette" #> attr(,"name") #> [1] "MotleyBlues"
